results.title: Down lands
results.creator_credit: Charles de Lautour, Humphrey Swingler, Film Producers Guild and Green Park Productions
results.brief_description: Part of the Pattern of Britain series. The Down lands region in Southern England, stretching from Dover to the Cotswolds, has been a famous sheep-raising area for centuries. The film illustrates the changes taking place in village life and in farming methods in the region; sheep raising is giving way to dairy and wheat farming, poultry raising and more diversified farming. With these changes the way of life in the villages is changing, bringing an end to the isolation of the past.

results.title: Down in the deep = Sunken treasure
results.creator_credit: George Gordon, Mannie Davis, Paul Terry and Terrytoon Cartoons
results.brief_description: Features Puddy the Pup. Finding a treasure map, Puddy and his young master set out to find the gold on the ocean floor.

results.title: Down and out
results.creator_credit: Gilbert Altschul Productions and Journal Films
results.brief_description: The film depicts one of the most common causes of injury in workshop situations - falling. It examines the common hazards which cause people to lose their balance; over-reaching, taking short cuts, failure to check eqiupment, and not looking where one is going.

results.title: Down a long way: the story of an oilwell
results.creator_credit: Bob Privett, British Petroleum and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description: Light-hearted animation describes methods of finding oil. Geologists can deduce the presence of a favourable underground formation from surface observations, and the geophysicist can then site a well, with some accuracy, by plotting the actual shape of the underground strata. Describes drilling and sampling operations which give access to the imprisoned oil.

results.title: Dover: spring 1947
results.creator_credit: Mary Beales, Data Film Productions and Papua New Guinea. Office of Information
results.brief_description: A study of the rebuilding program of the English Channel town of Dover, which suffered heavy damage from shellfire during WWII. The historic town is to be, very largely, rebuilt on a new site, and extensive use is to be made of recently developed prefabrication techniques. Good use of British humour gives this doco additional interest.

results.title: Douglas Mawson: the survivor
results.brief_description: During an expedition to Antarctica in 1912, Mawson’s two companions perished leaving him, ill and weak, to struggle back alone to a base camp at Commonwealth Bay. A reconstruction of the tragic expedition is the pivot of the documentary, which also includes interviews with the explorer-scientist’s daughters, contemporaries and students.

results.title: Double thread
results.creator_credit: Mary Field and G R Instruction
results.brief_description: How the daily routine is organised for the children’s own needs in a modern well-equipped nursery school in England. Every activity is designed to help the individual child’s development, and to encourage their adjustment to social and group relationships. The “double thread” refers to the inter-relations of home and kindergarten in the growing child’s life.

results.title: Dorothy Hewett
results.brief_description: Australia’s best known female playwright, Dorothy Hewett, looks back on her childhood influences and the place of music, poetry and art in her work.
results.description: Australia’s best known female playwright, Dorothy Hewett, looks back on her childhood influences and the place of music, poetry and art in her work.

results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: Dorothy Hewett
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers III”.
Dorothy Hewett reflects on her life as a playwright, poet, author and teacher. Hewett grew up in Western Australia and has been a writer all her life. A political, social and sexual rebel, she has created work which has often been controversial for its frankness and for the power of her female central characters. In this 1991 interview, Hewett discusses the professional and personal relationships that have enriched her life and inspired her writing. She also speaks about ageing and her struggle to overcome the loss of physical power. Research and interview: James Murdoch.
